utterance.speaker: Race announcer
utterance.content: …Calamari is still in the lead but Ample Parking is making strides he is now in fourth, third, and holding second place while Blue Calamari is at a steady speed… …And down the stretch they come! Ample Parking comes from behind and it’s Ample Parking by a nose! This is the last call for the third race. You may still wager if you hurry. Here’s your information on race number three…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Out of the way, cripple coming through.

utterance.speaker: Man in line in front of House
utterance.content: Um, sixth race at Golden Downs; I’ll take the two and the four. Hey, that’s my birthday! February 4th, 1963, you think that’s a good bet? What’s your birthday?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Take your time, don’t worry that there’s only thirty seconds to post.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Is there any way I can bet on the six and the three also? You know, for the year? All four horses, can I do that?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: He wants a $2 exactabox, 2, 4, 6, 3. Give him $24. Your turn.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ninth at Gulf Street and Park; five hundred on the 3 horse, Seminole Uprising to win.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Might as well burn your money.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll burn my winnings. Bigger flame.

utterance.speaker: Race announcer
utterance.content: Ladies and gentlemen, they’re at the post. The flag is up.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Same race. Termigator to win.

utterance.speaker: Race announcer
utterance.content: And they’re off!

utterance.speaker: Teller
utterance.content: Sorry, race just closed.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Damn it! She was 14 to 1, too.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, fat ass over there just saved you money.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: No way Seminole Uprising’s going to –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t bet on the horses, I bet on the jocks. My rider’s bulimic; purges after his weigh-ins; leaves a two pound pile at the starting gate, shaves valuable time off that final eighth.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Nice to have inside information.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is anybody here a doctor? You trying to cop a feel?

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: I took a CPR class at the Y.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That would be useful if she was having a heart attack instead of a seizure.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Seizure? Hold her tongue down?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you want to get a finger bitten off. Call an ambulance.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Methodist is three blocks down, I could drive her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just make the call.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: What the hell is that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How should I know? Tell the paramedics to take her to Princeton-Plainsboro. The doctor’s name is House.

utterance.speaker: Race announcer
utterance.content: And it’s Termigator winning by two lengths!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Since when does House hang out at OTB?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The man’s an addict.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Right, but addicted to pills, not gambling.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s the same thing! Drug abuse, drinking, gambling – they all fire up the same pleasure centers in the brain. An addict is an addict is –

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Gambling doesn’t take away his pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It does when I win. Hot OTB babe, has grand mal and inexplicable bruising. What up with that?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You were just standing there and she started to seize?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Spend as much time around the real people as I do, someone gets sick.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her platelets are 89, she’s anemic, and she has a blood alcohol level of 0.13.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hot OTB babe? Obviously a working girl, probably an STD, infection.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No fever, no infection.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Alcohol abuse explains it all. Causes seizures and affects her blood’s ability to clot, which causes bruising. Start her on heparin, she’ll be fine by morning.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Except for the fact that the bruises are not petechial, which means it’s not DIC.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So the bruises were caused by trauma. She probably got beat up by a boyfriend, or a pimp.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s that called when you judge someone before ever meeting them?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s a regular at OTB. Somehow I don’t see her holding down a 9-to-5 and going to PTA meetings.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was there. I have a 9-to-3 job.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It could be SLE, Familial Telangiectasia, or even Cushing’s.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good. Start with those.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Which one?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cushing’s. Explains the seizure and the bruising.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not the anemia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So she doesn’t eat a lot of meat.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: DIC brought on by alcohol abuse is far more likely. Do a full workup, H and P, and lab her up, LP, MRI –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whoa, whoa, whoa! Did you just, ever so subtly, order me to get her medical history?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cuddy put me in charge last week, so yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It was a pretend “in charge”, formality to get past the suits in Legal.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Right, those licensing board folk love to play dress-up and pretend.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey, no worries. I’ll let you keep your parking space.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can have it. You’ll also need my handicap placard. Bend over.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, you make a pretty convincing argument.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chase killed that woman, now Foreman’s in charge?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah, we have a pecking order here: if Cameron kills someone, Chase takes over. There’s a flowchart in the lobby. For the next three weeks you answer directly to Dr. Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And I expect you here for grand rounds at nine. By the way, I like sugar in my coffee.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If there’s a screw-up, it’s your screw-up. You won’t have Dr. House to fall back on.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: “Do you wear a seatbelt?” Is that really relevant to a seizure?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Skip it.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: How about, “Were you vaccinated for polio?” I think you gave me the form intended for FDR.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Will I like Teeny Tiny Moe in the fifth?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I went 4 for 6 yesterday. You want winners, cure me first. “Are you generally satisfied with your life?”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It does not ask that.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: You know; I was going to ask what a respectable doctor was doing in an OTB parlor. Somehow that question doesn’t seem relevant anymore.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What’s your excuse?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Turns me on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah? What else turns you on? Drugs? Casual sex? Rough sex? Casual rough sex? I’m a doctor, I need to know.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: No sex; just moved here. Haven’t even found a job yet. Don’t know anybody.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Came here without a job. That means you didn’t move here, you moved away from somewhere else. Does that hurt?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you on prescription meds? Hormones? Prednisone?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I already answered that one; I think it was question number 20-something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well yeah, and I could reach down and get it, but that would kinda spoil the whole “cool move.”

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I’m not on any medications.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You vegetarian?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: No, why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because you might have something called Cushing’s syndrome, which basically means that –

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: My pituitary is overproducing ACTH, which is causing my adrenal glands to push too much cortisol into my bloodstream.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What a coincidence. I’m a doctor, too.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Yeah, I had it last year. They did brain surgery, removed an adenoma from my pituitary.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Huh? What did you just say? “You were right, House, her pituitary tumor regrew, it is Cushing’s, uncanny how you do that….”

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Actually, it was Cameron’s idea.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, Cameron had three ideas. I chose one to encourage, to nurture –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, you’re all about the nurturing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You need a hug?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don’t see any regrowth. You get her medical records faxed over?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: “Work smart, not hard,” that’s my philosophy, boss.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Take that as a no. Anica, I need you to stay completely still.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Still don’t see anything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, so it’s a micro-adenoma, too small to see.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So small it’s not even there.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, it’s just a coincidence that I predicted a rare condition that she happened to have a year ago.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Results from her LP back yet?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Didn’t do an LP. Knew what she had.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Go do the LP.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, I need you to roll over on your side, kiss your kneecaps.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Party time. I thought it only took one doctor to do this.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m observing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s here to make sure I don’t paralyze you.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: You’ve done this before, right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Successfully?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s kidding. He’s an excellent doctor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m gonna numb the area with some lidocaine, and then we’re off to the races! See what I did there? I used horse racing jargon to make the patient feel more comfortable. Okay, here we go.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Ow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Felt like bone. Does that hurt?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: A little bit. What are you doing? Owwww.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Trying rounding your back a bit more.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re perfect just the way you are. Oops, that was all me.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Ow.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You might want to move down one vertebra.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is actually much harder than I remember.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Uhhh. My chest feels a little tight.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Try taking a deep breath. Dr. House, maybe I should take it from here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eighth time’s the charm.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You trying to piss off Foreman, huh?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just let –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: BP’s 240 over 140.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Turn that thing off, will you?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Take the needle out. Take the needle out!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. It’s a hypertensive crisis. Start her on IV low pressure drip, titrate to systolic less than 140, she’ll be fine. Cameron, meet me in my office.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: At the risk of sounding redundant, and right, again, she has Cushing’s. Cushing’s.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right, the fact that you mangled her LP has nothing to do with it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, it has everything to do with it. Cushing’s plus stress equals hypertensive crisis. Smart move, sending the rookie.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her initial symptoms could have been caused by alcohol-induced DIC. She had a hypertensive crisis because it’s been at least six hours since she had her last drink. She’s detoxing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The exact same moment that I’m futilely trying to give her an LP?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right, an invisible tumor on her pituitary is much more likely.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What if the tumor is somewhere else? There could be an ACTH-secreting tumor on her lung or pancreas.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s awfully rare.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not as rare as an invisible tumor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why didn’t they put you in charge instead of Foreman? Oh yeah, you’re the guy that killed that woman. Get a pan-man scan before she dies of cortisol OD.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fine, do it. But when you don’t find anything, put her on a Librium taper for the withdrawal and get her a bed in the rehab clinic.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lungs look clean. Pilar lymph nodes not enlarged.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Cuddy tapped Foreman to run the department. I didn’t even get asked.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Neither did I.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You were suspended.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I was kidding.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s the irony of women in charge; they don’t like other women in charge. What, you think it’s something else?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You sabotaged yourself. You went on a date with House, you slept with me. Putting you in charge of this department is like a sexual harassment suit waiting to happen.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, they’re really worried that I’m going to create a hostile work environment.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe that’s the problem. Being in charge means having to say no to House. Would you hire you for that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You ordered MRIs for the entire maternity ward?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was in a crazy mood. Good thing I got a new boss to back me up. Although I think one of those is actually necessary. Better comb through before you cancel them all.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What do you expect me to do, House? Quit? Cry?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, I expect you to act like what you are, my employee, my subordinate, my bitch.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, since you asked nicely…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My God, I can’t believe I got more than a year behind on my discharge summaries. Gotta get caught up. Oh no, wait! I’m not authorized to sign these anymore! Only you are.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Keep it coming. I’m not gonna break.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Scans showed a mass on her pancreas.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Looks malignant, probably inoperable. I’d give her two months.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: On the bright side, it still means I was right.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Where’s Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Dr. Foreman’s overseeing your case. He thought it’d be best if I spoke with you. We found a mass in your pancreas. It looks like cancer.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: So something in my pancreas caused me to have a seizure?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Probably, but the bigger point is a one-year survival rate for pancreatic cancer is less than 20%.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: So what’s the treatment?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We need to biopsy the mass to see what we’re dealing with. Then we can recommend options from there.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Sounds good.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I need your consent to do the biopsy. Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Wish me luck.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Good luck.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It was weird. She barely reacted at all.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’ve had people hug me and people take a swing at me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This was more like she didn’t even hear me.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Magnify three times.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House assisting. That is funny. Too bad Foreman’s gonna die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good afternoon. I’m going to be looking at your – Perfect. Excuse me. Need Dr. Foreman in Exam Room 1 for a consult. So when did this start?

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: A couple weeks ago. I didn’t want to get pregnant. Jake’s not into rubbers so I got on the jelly. You think I’m allergic or something?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have an infection. Gonna need a sample.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: I brought the jar.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I meant a sample of your – Okay, we have a neurological problem here.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: There’s something wrong with my brain?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh yeah. You can cover yourself up, got what I need.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What’s up?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Smell this. Smells like vaginosis, but it’s not really my call.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Great, I’ll be sure to put a gold star by your name on the board. Anica’s biopsy for pancreatic cancer was negative.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay, I’m gonna give you some antibiotics, and you probably shouldn’t have sex for awhile.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: How long?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: On an evolutionary basis, I’d recommend forever.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The mass in the pancreas is benign; it’s probably just scar tissue.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Good news, she’s not sick at all. Other than being an alcoholic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The labs you sent yesterday put her ACTH at 64 picograms per milliliter. She’s got Cushing’s, something set it off. It’s gotta be in her brain, set her up for a venous sampling.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There is another possibility.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Chase, hold on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How’d you get him trained so fast? Electronic collar? Got treats in your pocket?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She didn’t even read the consent form for the pancreatic biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Who reads those things?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe she didn’t read it because she knew there was nothing wrong with her. There is another explanation for the Cushing’s; maybe she injected herself with the ACTH. Her behavior suggests Munchausen’s. She’s had four hospitalizations in the last four months.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, being hospitalized a lot certainly points to nothing being wrong with you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She’s had zero symptoms since she got here. The scarring on her pancreas could be caused by injecting herself with a benzene and setting off the seizures.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s had brain surgery. You can fake a stomach ache; you can’t fake a brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You can fake an invisible one. We should check her apartment. Look for medications, syringes –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Venous sampling’s easier.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And more dangerous.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not if you get caught breaking in.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So don’t get caught, House.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why do you think Cuddy picked Foreman over me? Have I done something wrong or if there’s something I needed to improve on…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Would you shut up if I told you she wanted someone black?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How would you describe my leadership skills?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nonexistent. Otherwise, excellent.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s more to being a leader than being a jerk!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The world will never know.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, no way. It just snowed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yesterday, streets are clear.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: My car is right there.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s construction on Elm. Bike will be faster.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s even books in the bathroom.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, either she’s very smart or she has a severe fiber deficiency.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: She’s got an appointment with her ophthalmologist on Tuesday and an appointment with her gynecologist on Thursday. Multiple appointments with multiple doctors, symptom of Munchausen’s.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or, just thinking outside the box, here, she has a vagina, and trouble reading. There’s three pairs of reading glasses, each with different prescriptions, which would be explained by a tumor pressing on the optic nerve.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because you’re looking for her to have a tumor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And you are looking for… A person with Munchausen’s syndrome drinks battery acid; they don’t go to an ophthalmologist to get their pupils dilated.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: An ophthalmologist is a doctor. Attention is attention.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How many hospitals have you contacted? Has one doctor said she’s crazy? It’s not Munchausen’s!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s not your call.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you think she’s got Munchausen’s then obviously you’ve got something to show the man! A syringe in her apartment, a bottle of ACTH.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Munchausen’s patients are good at covering their tracks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, right, so the fact that we found nothing proves that there’s something.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Look at the pathology reports from the surgery she had in Chicago. They removed 30% of her pituitary, they found no tumor!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s possible the surgeons just missed it. In that kind of surgery, you’re just cutting and hoping –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course! We’re both right! Excellent solution. Everybody’s happy. Come on, step up, Foreman. If you think I’m right, order me and stick a needle in her brain, and if you think Cameron’s right, send the patient home. Either she’ll be fine or she’ll die.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Do the venous sampling. Get her consent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nice move, boss. Way to cover your ass.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I just agreed with you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not because you think I’m right. You’re just taking the safe route. You’re a wuss. Don’t worry, your secret’s safe with me. Hey Wilson, guess what Foreman just did!

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: This is a consent form to stick a wire into your brain. It’s important for hospitals to get these signed for procedures that are completely unnecessary.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Then why are you doing it?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because you’re mentally ill. You injected yourself with ACTH to induce Cushing’s to get attention from doctors, and so far it’s worked.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I’d like to see another doctor.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not giving you what you want?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I don’t want a bitch.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just sign the forms, okay, and I’ll get out of here. Hopefully for you, whatever you injected yourself with won’t wear off before you get the fun of a caring and concerned doctor cutting into your head.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You chose me to make House miserable, didn’t you?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Apparently, he’s making you miserable. That’s impressive.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Find someone else.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No. For the first time in six years I’m getting copied on experimental tests and procedures. Clinic hours have been logged and completed. You’ve given me four months of House’s dictation so I can finally bill insurance companies –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I only did that stuff to prove that he couldn’t make me miserable.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, way to go! Now everybody’s getting what they need, even House! He gets to play mad scientist and this department runs smoothly.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So I’m stuck with this for the next three weeks.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, maybe longer. Would you be interested if this wasn’t just pretend?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What did Mommy say; I don’t get any candy in my stocking?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Patient being prepped for the venous sampling?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah. Mentally ill patient is right on track for a pointless procedure.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, we get your objection. Foreman. Are you sure? That doesn’t make any sense, check it again. We got to delay the venous sample.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Why, her urine turning orange?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How would you know that?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Because that’s what rifampin does.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’s not on antibiotics.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But if a Munchausen’s patient thinks she’s about to get busted, she sees pills labeled “Dangerous: Might cause seizures,” she might grab a couple. And if that label were accidentally on a bottle of antibiotics and if that bottle was accidentally left in her room –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You set her up?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Might have. It’s Munchausen’s. All this, she did to herself.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I don’t know what the hell you’re talking about! I had a seizure, I’m sick, I need your help!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Not from this department. The half-life of rifampin is three hours, after that you’ll get your psych referral, and your discharge papers.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: You know, just because you stick your fingers down your throat doesn’t mean the rest of us are screwed up.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I guess when cooperation fails you move on to hostility.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I didn’t do this to myself.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: 100% commitment. Sign of a good liar.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Also the sign of a sociopath. What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Correcting your last note. We can’t discharge her, she’s sick. Anybody ever tell you, you write like a girl?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What? You got some other explanation for orange urine? It’s Munchausen’s.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Correct, but not complete.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You just don’t wanna admit that she skunked you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: At the end of “The Boy Who Cried Wolf,” the wolf really does come, and he eats the sheep, and the boy, and his parents.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The wolf doesn’t eat the parents!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It does when I tell it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re not telling the story now, I am.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look, I checked her records. All her hospitalizations were for different things. Brain tumor, fainting spells, skin rashes, seizures… she’s had every blood test known to man and the results are all over the map. There’s only one constant, low HCT. The anemia’s real.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There’s a million things she could have taken to have done that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: True. Could just be her MO. She self-induces two illnesses, one always changes, one never does. Or maybe she has Munchausen’s and aplastic anemia, which would mean without proper treatment she’d continue to get sicker, weaker; eventually she’ll start bleeding internally and die.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s not getting sicker.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She will!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If her bone marrow was dying the entire blood panel would be affected. Her white count’s normal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So far. We need to do a bone marrow biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, no more tests.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look, you kick her to the curb with a Munchausen’s diagnosis; you’re guaranteeing that no doctor will ever listen to her again.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We do more tests we’ll only be feeding her psychosis. The more attention we give her, the more she’ll want.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What if she doesn’t know we’re testing her?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House, you were wrong. Live with it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s probably some blood left over from previous tests.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Blood tests alone can’t confirm aplastic anemia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, I know. That’s why I want to do a bone marrow biopsy. But blood tests could show a systemic disease, viral or a toxin cause.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fine. You wanna test the extra blood, knock yourself out. But the patient is off-limits.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And if the results are positive? I get my biopsy? It’s the safe way to go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need all of these tests and a PCR done on this sample.

utterance.speaker: Lab tech
utterance.content: You’re gonna need more blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Patient’s empty.

utterance.speaker: Lab tech
utterance.content: Then I can’t do it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can try.

utterance.speaker: Lab tech
utterance.content: i can try to look like Salma Hayek, that’s not gonna make it happen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You may not have Salma’s ass, but she doesn’t have your eyes.

utterance.speaker: Lab tech
utterance.content: Yeah, right. How soon you need it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Dr. Wilson, can I talk to you about something in confidence?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s about House.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, then no. Fine, I won’t say anything.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Do you think there’s any way House would take me seriously as his boss?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Where is this coming from? Did Cuddy say something?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We talked. She intimated.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And you want my advice on how to usurp him? It’s very ancient Rome; you’ll need a toga, of course, a sword…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not a coup. I just want to figure out some way we can work together. I mean, I keep the team running from an administrative point of view; House doesn’t have to deal with the red tape. It’s a win-win.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m sure he’ll see it that way.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You have any advice on how to approach him? Deal with the guy?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But you won’t tell him we talked.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. There’s no way this is going to happen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: “See him walking down that street, so I ask you very confidentially, ain’t he sweet?” Epstein-Barr titers are through the roof, most common viral cause of aplastic anemia. So what I’m saying is, “Just cast an eye in his direction, oh me oh my, ain’t that perfection –“

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fetal hemoglobin’s also elevated.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eh, just a wee bit. Could indicate –

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Uh, you see that in sickle-cell.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not all sickle-cell patients are black.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: None of her other blood panels showed any sign of sickle-cell, which means either something’s changed drastically since yesterday, or this isn’t her blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Of course it is! Metaphorically. Look, I couldn’t do the tests. I tried, there wasn’t enough blood left over. If you just let me do the biopsy…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No way, I just got back from a suspension.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And if it wasn’t for me, you would have been fired.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Why don’t you just get the sample yourself? Since when do you care what your boss said?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t care what anybody says, I care what they do. Right now, Blackpoleon Blackaparte has got the nurses on red alert, I can’t get into the patient’s room. So come on, I’ll draw the enemy fire, you outflank them, get in there, get the bone marrow sample.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Can’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who are you more afraid of?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m not afraid of Foreman. I agree with him, all the tests back him up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: All the tests have not been done. You do realize that Blackaparte’s reign is only temporary.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I also realize that no matter what I do, you’re still gonna treat me like crap.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Crap is a relative term.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Never even made it into the room.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Nurses called the attending as soon as the trocar was ordered.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You used her real name?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I just processed your patient’s discharge papers. She’s on her way out now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, wait up! It’s all right, she’s going to stay.

utterance.speaker: Taxi driver
utterance.content: Wonderful.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, bite me.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I don’t need to hear the riot act again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How’d you like another medical test?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sit.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So you don’t crack your skull when you pass out. Just do it. You know what colchicine is?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, don’t feel bad. It’s for gout. It’s got nothing to do with anything you’ve ever pretended to have.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I’m not pretending to have any –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shut up. Colchicine decimates your white blood cells, leaves almost no trace. Great for faking your way into hospitals.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I didn’t fake my way –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shut up. You’ve been doing this for years. Don’t worry, it’s probably not your fault. When you were a kid, you had a close relative with a chronic disease, probably sister. And you saw all the attention she got while you were left alone, ignored, and it really, seriously screwed you up.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I did not have a relative –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Shut up! I’m trying to give you what you want, and save your life. You have aplastic anemia.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: What, are you trying to scare me now?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It means you’re not just sick in the head. The problem is, the rest of you appears well, so I’ve got to make you seem as sick as you’re supposed to be by injecting you with a drug that simulates the symptoms that you actually have. All you need to know is, you’ve hit the Munchausen’s jackpot. I’m going to give you a cocktail of insulin for seizure, and colchicine to kill your white blood count. This will absolutely confirm my diagnosis of aplastic anemia. There is one small catch. If you’ve actually done something to yourself to cause the anemia, then I’m wrong, and if I do what I plan to do, then the treatment will kill you instead of saving you. So I need to know, have you been taking anything besides the insulin, the ACTH, and the pills Cameron left in your room?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good. Give me your arm.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: It was my mom. She had MS. She was in and out of hospitals all the time. People were always trying to do things for her, bring her food, or brush her hair, make her happy. People cared. She died when I was 16. Then there was no one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Boo hoo.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I obviously can’t be around when it happens.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Well, what are you gonna do, you’re just gonna leave me –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Relax. You know the drill. People walk by here all the time, you’ll be fine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So, barely out the door and she has another seizure.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She must have somehow grabbed insulin on the way out.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Once she’s stable we need to get her out of here, before she does more damage to herself.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We can’t. Her white count’s down.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, I missed that. My hearing’s been off since the Ricky Martin concert, some chulo kicked me in the head.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: White count, hematocrit and platelets are all off. The bone marrow’s shutting down, she actually has aplastic anemia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Say what?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: All her other labs show nothing that –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Labs schmabs. A good diagnostician reads between the labs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You were right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, hey, hey, we’re not here to play the blame game. These things happen. Sometimes doctors send people out on the street to die after other doctors warned them that they were sending them out on the street to die. There’s no way you could know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ll go give her the news.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Who are you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m Dr. Foreman; I’m in charge of your case. You have aplastic anemia, which means your bone marrow is shut down. Your body can’t make new blood anymore.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Are you sure?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I went back and checked your old records. It makes sense. The aplastic anemia has apparently been developing for months. I’m sorry, we should have caught it earlier.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: So it’s not just the latest white count that’s leading you to feel this way?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I know this is scary, but a bone marrow transplant could cure you.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: A marrow transplant could kill me.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The other option is weekly blood transfusions, injections of GCSF. It’s a lifelong regimen.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Yeah, I don’t want that.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You sure? I don’t want to be cruel, here, but you’ve jumped through a lot of hoops to get this sort of attention.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: I just want to be healthy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s not so much fun when you’re actually sick.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’ll check the registry, see if there’s a donor match.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We have to kill all the old bone marrow before we get to the new stuff. You’ll have no immune system. We’ll keep you in a sterile room for two weeks to make sure everything’s dead, then we’ll give you the donor marrow. It will take another couple weeks until it takes hold. You won’t feel a thing. If you get uncomfortable for any reason and need to talk, don’t yell. Walls are four inches thick, lead. Use the microphone. Are you ready?

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Okay. Where’s Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Turn it off.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Now what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How long has she been in there?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Three minutes, what’s going on?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She doesn’t have aplastic anemia. She has an infection.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, her white count would be through the roof, hers is on the floor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The body does crazy things.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The body does crazy things. Well, that explains everything!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She had no fever.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because her self-inflicted Cushing’s suppressed her immune system, stopped her from having a fever, hid the infection. Clostridium perfringens could cause the bruising, the schistocytes, the anemia…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Explains everything except the white count.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Augmentin is a lot safer than destroying her immune system, why don’t we try that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Whoa, whoa, whoa. You’re taking the safe course? What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s lots of explanations for low white count.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Name one that fits her case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Colchicine. I figured that she got her hands on it and just, uh, self-medicated.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s brilliant of her. Take the exact medication that would confirm your diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People do crazy things.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You injected her against her will just so you could be right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She consented.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She’s mentally ill!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She smells oh, so sweet.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She would have gotten sicker when I said she was gonna get sicker except Cameron dosed her with antibiotics. Just hold this.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Is everything okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hold my finger. Grapey. You have a bacterium. It’s on all of us, but the bruises you gave yourself with the Cushing’s made it a lovely home. Bacteria moved in, parked their cars on the lawn, there goes the neighborhood. And by neighborhood, I mean your internal organs. So, should we put her on the Augmentin, boss, or do you think she infected herself with grapes? I love the smell of pus in the morning. Smells like… victory.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If you were serious about the offer, I’m serious about accepting. I’d like to run the department. You said it yourself, things run smooth.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Except for the part where House went behind your back and KO’d the patient with insulin and colchicine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There was no reason to suspect an infection. Even House didn’t think it was an infection. You would have done the same thing I did.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And I’d be just as wrong. What House did was insane, but he saved her life.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He got lucky.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He got her to admit she’s got a problem. She’s agreed to outpatient treatment. He gets lucky a lot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Did you ever really intend to give me this job, or were you just trying to stop me from stepping down?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, you’ve got two more weeks in charge. Hopefully the next case will go better.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She should have died. House is not a hero. A person who has the guts to break a bad rule, they’re a hero. House doesn’t break rules, he ignores them. He’s not Rosa Parks, he’s an anarchist. All he stands for is the right for everyone to grab whatever they want, whenever they want. You tell doctors that’s okay, your mortality rate is gonna go through the roof.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kinda digging this whole “Foreman in charge” thing. Frees me up to watch my soaps, catch a movie in the afternoon, have lunch with you…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s a big change for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now Cuddy’s on Foreman’s ass, not mine.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You couldn’t live with Foreman as your boss.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why not? People could change, you know?

utterance.speaker: Doctor
utterance.content: Your white count is way down. We’re going to need to admit you, just run a few tests.

utterance.speaker: Anica
utterance.content: Whatever you think is best.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Last race at Belmont, put it all on the five. To win.
